abstract.text: The Tevatron proton-antiproton collider at Fermilab with its centre of mass energy of 1.96 TeV allows for pair production of top quarks and the study of top quark decay properties.

This report reflects the current status of measurements of the W boson helicity in top quark decays and the ratio of top quark branching fractions as well as searches for neutral current top quark decays and pair production of fourth generation t' quarks, performed by the D0 Collaboration utilising datasets of up to 5.4 fb −1 .

body_text.text: Introduction
With a mass of m t = 173.2 ± 0.9 GeV [1], the top quark is the most massive fundamental particle known to date.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Top quarks are mainly produced in pairs via the strong interaction, with a cross section of σ tt = 7.3 +0.5 −0.6 pb [2] in pp collisions at √ s = 1.96 TeV.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In the framework of the Standard Model (SM), top quarks decay almost exclusively into W bosons and b quarks.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Consequently, top quark pair events contain a b and ab quark from the tt decay, and the remaining final state to be observed depends on the decay mode of the two W bosons.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The analyses presented here focus on two signatures:
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: (i) events where both W bosons decay leptonically, resulting in a final state containing two isolated high-p T leptons, missing transverse energy E T corresponding to the two neutrinos and two (b-) jets (dilepton events) and
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: (ii) events where one W boson decays leptonically, the other one hadronically, resulting in one isolated high-p T lepton, E T and four jets (lepton + jets events).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: As leptons only electrons and muons are considered in these analysis channels, including those from leptonic τ decays.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Searches for New Physics in Top Quark Pair Decays
Measurement of the W Boson Helicity
Top quark decays in the SM proceed via the left-handed charged current weak interaction, which results in a suppression of right-handed W bosons.
body_text.section: Measurement of the W Boson Helicity

body_text.text: The expected fractions of the three possible helicity states of the W boson are: longitudinal fraction f 0 ≈ 69%, left-handed fraction f − ≈ 31% and right-handed fraction f + ≈ 10 −3 [3].
body_text.section: Measurement of the W Boson Helicity

body_text.text: The W boson helicity is reflected in the angular distribution cos θ * of its decay products, with θ * being the angle of the down-type decay products of the W boson (charged lepton, d-or s-quark) in the W boson rest frame relative to the top quark direction.
body_text.section: Measurement of the W Boson Helicity

body_text.text: Any observation of f + at the percent level would signal new physics beyond the SM.
body_text.section: Measurement of the W Boson Helicity

body_text.text: D0 measures the W boson helicity using a dataset corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 5.4 fb −1 , using both lepton + jets and dilepton final states of tt decays [4].
body_text.section: Measurement of the W Boson Helicity

body_text.text: Since the measurement is still expected to be limited by sample statistics, the event selection in each channel is optimised for tt acceptance, using multivariate likelihood discriminants based on event topology and object kinematics.
body_text.section: Measurement of the W Boson Helicity

body_text.text: In the lepton + jets channel, the event kinematics is obtained from the best kinematic fit to the tt event hypothesis, which enables the calculation of cos θ * for the leptonic W boson decay.
body_text.section: Measurement of the W Boson Helicity

body_text.text: The hadronic W boson decay is utilised as well to evaluate | cos θ * |, which does not permit discrimination between rightand left-handed W bosons, but still adds information to further constrain f 0 .
body_text.section: Measurement of the W Boson Helicity

body_text.text: In the dilepton events, m t = 172.5 GeV is assumed and cos θ * is obtained for each top quark as the average over all possible solutions of the event kinematics, taking lepton and jet energy resolutions into account by varying the energies within their uncertainties.
body_text.section: Measurement of the W Boson Helicity

body_text.text: By comparing the observed angular distributions in data with templates of background and tt signal with varying W boson helicity admixtures, f 0 and f + can be extracted in a simultaneous fit (f − = 1 − f + − f 0 ).
body_text.section: Measurement of the W Boson Helicity

body_text.text: This modelindependent fit yields: f 0 = 0.669 ± 0.078 (stat.)± 0.065 (syst.), f + = 0.023 ± 0.041 (stat.)± 0.034 (syst.), in excellent agreement with the SM expectation.
body_text.section: Measurement of the W Boson Helicity

body_text.text: Search for Neutral Current Top Decays
Transitions between quarks of different flavour but identical charge (flavour changing neutral currents, FCNC) are forbidden at lowest order and heavily suppressed at higher orders in the SM.
body_text.section: Search for Neutral Current Top Decays

body_text.text: The decay t → Zq (with q = u, c) thus is expected to occur with a branching fraction of O(10 −14 ) [5], well out of reach of experimental sensitivity.
body_text.section: Search for Neutral Current Top Decays

body_text.text: Any observation of FCNC decays would indicate physics beyond the SM.
body_text.section: Search for Neutral Current Top Decays

body_text.text: D0 performs a search for tt → W bZq + X decays based on a dataset corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 4.1 fb −1 , using the trilepton final state ℓ ′ νℓl + jets for the first time in this kind of search [6].
body_text.section: Search for Neutral Current Top Decays

body_text.text: This signature benefits from low background contributions, but also suffers from limited statistics.
body_text.section: Search for Neutral Current Top Decays

body_text.text: After a basic preselection reflecting the decay signature, signal and background (mainly diboson and V + jets production) are separated using distributions of jet multiplicity, scalar sum of the transverse momenta of leptons, jets and E T (H T ), and the reconstructed top quark mass from the t → Zq decay.
body_text.section: Search for Neutral Current Top Decays

body_text.text: All observed distributions are consistent with the SM background contributions, and consequently 95% C.L. limits on FCNC decays of tt are derived:
body_text.section: Search for Neutral Current Top Decays

body_text.text: with an expected limit of 3.8 %.
body_text.section: Search for Neutral Current Top Decays

body_text.text: This is currently the world's best limit on B(t → Zq).
body_text.section: Search for Neutral Current Top Decays

body_text.text: Search for Fourth Generation t ′ Quark Pair Production

While a fourth generation of fermions with a light neutrino (m ν < m Z /2) has been ruled out by electroweak precision data, the constraints on a fourth generation are much relaxed if the neutrino is sufficiently heavy.
body_text.section: Search for Fourth Generation t ′ Quark Pair Production

body_text.text: For example, a fourth generation t ′ quark mass of 400 GeV can be compatible with electroweak precision measurements, and the mass splitting relative to the corresponding b ′ quark is constrained to be small, leading to a preferred decay t ′ → W q (q = d, s, b) [7].
body_text.section: Search for Fourth Generation t ′ Quark Pair Production

body_text.text: Based on a dataset with an integrated luminosity of 5.3 fb −1 , D0 searches for pair production of fourth generation up-type quarks (t ′t′ ), assuming the intrinsic t ′ width is smaller than the detector resolution and the decay always proceeds via W q [8].
body_text.section: Search for Fourth Generation t ′ Quark Pair Production

body_text.text: Consequently, the t ′t′ decay chain is identical to that of the top quark pair production, and the lepton + jets final state is used for the search with no b-jet identification applied.
body_text.section: Search for Fourth Generation t ′ Quark Pair Production

body_text.text: To separate the signal from SM background processes, the observed events are compared with signal and background contributions in two-dimensional histograms of the scalar sum of lepton-p T , jet-p T and E T (H T ) versus t ′ mass m f it from a kinematic fit to the event hypothesis.
body_text.section: Search for Fourth Generation t ′ Quark Pair Production

body_text.text: Based on the observed agreement between data and the SM contributions, 95% C.L. limits are derived on the t ′t′ production cross section as a function of m t ′ .
body_text.section: Search for Fourth Generation t ′ Quark Pair Production

body_text.text: While in the e + jets channel reasonable agreement between data and simulation is observed, in the µ + jets channel an excess of data over SM background is visible around m f it = 325 GeV.
body_text.section: Search for Fourth Generation t ′ Quark Pair Production

body_text.text: However, the data are best described with a t ′t′ production cross section 3.2 ± 1.1 times the predicted cross section for m t ′ = 325 GeV.
body_text.section: Search for Fourth Generation t ′ Quark Pair Production

body_text.text: The probability of observing an excess of at least this size from the SM background processes alone corresponds to 2.5 standard deviations.
body_text.section: Search for Fourth Generation t ′ Quark Pair Production

body_text.text: Combining the observations from both channels, t ′t′ production can be excluded at 95% C.L. for m t ′ < 285 GeV,
body_text.section: Search for Fourth Generation t ′ Quark Pair Production

body_text.text: with an expected exclusion below 320 GeV.
body_text.section: Search for Fourth Generation t ′ Quark Pair Production

body_text.text: Measurement of B(t → Wb)/B(t → Wq)
The  [9].
body_text.section: Measurement of B(t → Wb)/B(t → Wq)

body_text.text: Deviations of R from unity could for example be a sign for the presence of a fourth heavy quark generation or non-SM top quark decay modes.
body_text.section: Measurement of B(t → Wb)/B(t → Wq)

body_text.text: D0 measures R in a dataset corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 5.4 fb −1 , using both the lepton + jets and dilepton tt decay channels [10].
body_text.section: Measurement of B(t → Wb)/B(t → Wq)

body_text.text: In the lepton + jets channels, the number of identified b-jets (0, 1, ≥2) is used together with a multivariate kinematic discriminant to separate the tt signal from background in subsamples dominated by background in order to extract R simultaneously with the tt production cross section σ tt , yielding R = 0.95 ± 0.07 (stat. + syst.) and σ tt = 7.90 +0.79 −0.67 (stat. + syst.) pb.
body_text.section: Measurement of B(t → Wb)/B(t → Wq)

body_text.text: In the dilepton channels, the lowest value of a neural network b-jet identification algorithm applied to the leading jets in each event is used as a discriminant, yielding R = 0.86 ± 0.05 (stat. + syst.) and σ tt = 8.19 +1.06 −0.92 (stat. + syst.) pb.
body_text.section: Measurement of B(t → Wb)/B(t → Wq)

body_text.text: These measurements allow the extraction of σ tt without assuming B(t → W b) = 1 as usually done in tt cross section measurements.
body_text.section: Measurement of B(t → Wb)/B(t → Wq)

body_text.text: Combining both measurements yields: R = 0.90 ± 0.04 (stat. + syst.) and σ tt = 7.74 +0.67 −0.57 (stat. + syst.) pb.
body_text.section: Measurement of B(t → Wb)/B(t → Wq)

body_text.text: The cross section measurement is in good agreement with the SM expectation, and the R measurement is within approximately 2.5 standard deviations of the SM expectation, being the most precise measurement to date.
body_text.section: Measurement of B(t → Wb)/B(t → Wq)

body_text.text: Summary
D0 is pursuing a wealth of top quark physics analyses that probe the validity of the SM, a few of which are presented in this report.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: So far, no evidence for new physics phenomena has been found in top quark decays.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: The search continues now both at the Tevatron and the LHC, and will include updates to the analyses presented here.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: ratio of top quark branching fractions R can be expressed via CKM matrix elements as R = B(t → W b)/ Σ q=d,s,b B(t → W q)= |V tb | 2 / Σ q=d,s,b |V tq | 2 and provides therefore a measure of the relative size of |V tb | compared to |V td | and |V ts |.

Within the framework of the SM, assuming a unitary 3×3 CKM matrix and insignificance of non-W boson decay modes of the top quark, the above expression simplifies to R = |V tb | 2 and R is strongly constrained from global CKM fits: R = 0.99830 +00006 −00009
